articles.title: FEBRUARY 1985
articles.summary: This document outlines the astronomical events and club activities for February and early March 1985, including general meetings, star parties, a field expedition, and moon phases. Key events feature a presentation on Schmidt corrector plate fabrication and the announcement of the 5th Annual Astronomical Auction. It also mentions an upcoming Messier Marathon and board nominations.

articles.title: AND THE LIGHT SHINES IN DARKNESS
articles.summary: Carol and Barry Beaman describe running a public viewing session at Quarry Hill Observatory where they encountered a partially blind visitor eager to see Saturn through the 12.5" reflector. Barry guided the man to the eyepiece, who, despite his severe visual impairment, exclaimed with joy upon seeing the 'light' of the planet. This emotional experience deeply moved both the man and the other visitors present.

articles.title: THE ARTIFICIAL COMET
articles.summary: Don Machholz recounts his observation of an artificial satellite's cloud release, dubbed 'THE ARTIFICIAL COMET,' on December 27, 1984, after real clouds prevented the originally scheduled Christmas morning viewing. Using binoculars and a telescope, he observed the cloud expand rapidly, forming a 'wrinkle' and a faint tail, appearing as a fuzzy star near Spica. The event, occurring 70,000 miles from Earth, remained faint, never exceeding magnitude 4 and rarely visible to the naked eye.

articles.title: BY: JOHN GLEASON
articles.summary: John Gleason is editing the 1985 Membership roster and requests members whose names are listed to provide their missing telephone numbers by calling his number or waiting for the updated roster in March '85. Additionally, the article announces the SJAA's 30th anniversary on August 26, 1985, and invites long-time members to share historical information for an upcoming publication.

articles.title: BY: ERICA GOODE
articles.summary: The article announces a $70 million grant from the William M. Keck Foundation to Caltech, funding the construction of the world's most powerful optical telescope atop Mauna Kea, Hawaii. This 10-meter segmented-mirror telescope, designed by UC scientists, is slated for construction in 1986 and expected to begin operations by 1992. Jointly managed by UC and Caltech, the observatory will allow astronomers to study the early universe, despite initial UC aspirations for sole use and greater financial contribution.

articles.title: BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: Don Machholz discusses the phenomenon of Venus casting a visible shadow, noting that the planet is currently at its brightest (magnitude -4.6) in the evening sky. He encourages observers to try and see this shadow using a white piece of paper and an object like a hand or pencil, suggesting it's an interesting observation and potential photography subject.

articles.title: DEEP SKY NOTES -- FEBRUARY
articles.summary: This article details visual observing challenges and techniques for deep-sky objects located around Zeta Orionis, the easternmost star in Orion's belt. It provides specific tips for splitting Zeta Orionis itself, observing the emission nebula NGC 2024, reflection nebulae NGC 2023 and IC 432, and the elusive Horsehead Nebula (IC 434 and B33). The author recommends using off-axis masks, various nebula filters, and specific magnifications, often placing Zeta Orionis just outside the field of view to counter its glare.

articles.title: SOLAR ECLIPSE 84'
articles.summary: The Peninsula Astronomical Society is hosting "SOLAR ECLIPSE 84'" on Friday, February 8th at 8:00 PM in Appreciation Hall on the Foothill College Campus. This presentation will bring the experience of a total solar eclipse to attendees through color slides, prints, and movies narrated by veteran eclipse chasers Jacques Guertin and Ernie Piini. It will feature astrophotography from multiple renowned photographers who have published their work in major astronomy magazines.

articles.title: COLD FEET
articles.summary: The article "COLD FEET" by Paul Barton shares personal anecdotes and practical advice on preventing cold feet in cold weather, especially when moving from a warm environment outdoors. It details how perspiration can undermine the insulation of wool socks and suggests a method involving drying gear, cooling feet, and briefly chilling them before donning heavy socks and boots. The piece also includes nostalgic reflections on historical cold weather customs from northern states, highlighting the persistent challenge of keeping warm.

articles.title: ASTRO ADS
articles.summary: This advertisement offers a vintage Unitron 4-inch equatorial refractor telescope, Model 152, from around 1970. It includes all original accessories, a motor drive, and a modified drawtube to accept 1.25-inch eyepieces. The telescope is available for $1000 (firm) and can be purchased from William R. Billings in Newark, CA.

articles.title: QUESTION OF THE MONTH
articles.summary: The 'Question of the Month' poses an intriguing query: 'Why are there so many ladybugs at professional observatories?' This question suggests an exploration into the environmental or ecological factors that might attract these insects to astronomical facilities.

articles.title: BY: DENNI MEDLOCK
articles.summary: This article shares humorous anecdotes and memorable experiences of amateur astronomers traveling with their large, portable telescopes to various observing sites and conventions. It highlights the frequent confusion, curiosity, and sometimes surprising recognition they encountered from the general public who often mistook their telescopes for other objects or were simply bewildered by the unusual cargo. The stories illustrate the unique challenges and joys of transporting astronomical equipment.

articles.title: BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: This article, authored by Don Machholz, provides an update on comet observations, noting no new discoveries or recoveries in the past month but highlighting three currently visible comets: Levy-Rudenko (1984k), Shoemaker (1984s), and Periodic Comet Schwassee (1984n), with detailed positional data and observing notes for early 1985. It also reviews 1984 as a record-tying year for comet discoveries and recoveries, emphasizing contributions by professional astronomers and the Shoemaker team. The article briefly mentions Halley's Comet, noting its faintness.

articles.title: WHAT GOES AROUND COMES AROUND--HALLEY'S COMET
articles.summary: This article outlines the anticipated 1984-1986 apparition of Halley's Comet, detailing its three distinct passages with predicted magnitudes, declinations, and optimal viewing periods for observers. It provides guidance for amateur astronomers on how and when to best observe the comet, emphasizing the importance of dark skies and suggesting learning constellations. The piece includes specific astronomical data for early 1985, forecasting naked-eye visibility in late 1985, particularly for northern hemisphere observers.

articles.title: BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: The article announces the Seventh Annual Messier Marathon, to be held over two weekends: March 15-17 at Loma Prieta and March 22-24 at Grant Ranch Park. Participants aim to observe as many of Charles Messier's 110 celestial objects as possible in one night. The text provides detailed directions, logistical information, and tips for attendees, noting that not everyone stays all night or focuses solely on Messier objects.

articles.title: BY: BOB FINGERHUT
articles.summary: This article details the revised 1985 Space Shuttle launch schedule, outlining six missions involving Discovery and Challenger with various payloads including communication satellites, Spacelab modules, and the retrieval of the Long Duration Exposure Facility. It also reports on the successful launch of the NOAA-F weather satellite, the Soviet Union's Vega-1 and Vega-2 probes destined for Venus and Halley's Comet, and a USSR spaceplane test. Additionally, the European Space Agency approved the Eureca retrievable space platform, and discussions are underway for a potential joint US/USSR manned space flight.

articles.title: ATM coatings
articles.summary: This document advertises a service for telescope mirror coatings, specializing in aluminum coatings with silicon monoxide over-coating. It provides a price list for various mirror sizes, from 4Â¼" to 16", and details additional charges for old coating removal, a minimum charge, and instructions regarding postage and return shipping.

articles.title: GENERAL MEETINGS:
articles.summary: This document provides detailed logistical information for general meetings held at the University of Santa Clara, Alumni Science Hall, Room 102. It includes comprehensive driving directions from both north and south Hwy 17 exits, clarifies parking and building access instructions, and states that meetings begin promptly at 8 PM.

articles.title: INDOOR STAR PARTIES:
articles.summary: An indoor star party is scheduled to take place at the Los Gatos Red Cross Building, located at 18011 Los Gatos-Saratoga Rd., opening at 8 PM. Detailed driving directions are provided, starting from Hwy 17 South to the venue's parking lot via Rose Ave.

articles.title: GRANT RANCH COUNTY PARK:
articles.summary: Grant Ranch County Park is a newly designated observing site for the SJAA, located on Mt. Hamilton Road, halfway between San Jose and Lick Observatory. The article provides detailed directions, including how to access Mt. Hamilton Road from Hwy 680, and notes that the park's front gate will be locked after sunset, requiring the combination 4565 to open.

articles.title: HENRY COE STATE PARK:
articles.summary: This document provides detailed driving directions to Henry Coe State Park, instructing visitors to take Hwy 101 South to the East Dunne Exit and proceed approximately 11 miles. It outlines specific access information for the park's locked gate, including a club combination (4565), and emphasizes the importance of relocking the gate and using parking lights only after dark.

articles.title: FREMONT PEAK STATE PARK:
articles.summary: This document provides detailed driving directions to Fremont Peak State Park, specifically to the Coulter Camp overflow area where the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) sets up. It also includes a reminder to use parking lights only after dark at the site.

articles.title: OFFICERS:
articles.summary: This document lists the current officers of an organization, detailing their titles, names, addresses, and phone numbers. The listed positions include President, Vice-President, Secretary, and Treasurer, along with their respective contact details in California.

articles.title: BOARD OF DIRECTORS:
articles.summary: This document snippet lists the members of the Board of Directors with their contact phone numbers, along with the Ephemeris Editor, John Gleason, including his full mailing address. It serves as a directory for key personnel within an organization.

articles.title: EMPLOYMENT OPENINGS AT LUMICON
articles.summary: Lumicon, an astronomy-related company, is expanding in 1985 after five years of record growth and is seeking to fill several employment openings. Positions available include telephone sales, order entry, purchasing, inventory, shipping, and advertising, with starting salaries ranging from $12,000 to $18,000 per year. Interested individuals who combine a love for astronomy with enjoyable work are encouraged to send their resumes or call for more information.
